awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: LEAP: Learning, Accelerating, And Empowering Embodied Robot Technology Use Within The Construction Industry
awd_abstract_narration:
The construction industry employs millions of workers in the United States and is a cornerstone sector for the US economy. Unfortunately, productivity growth has stagnated compared to other economic sectors, with the stagnation often attributed to low productivity rates, labor shortages, an aging workforce, and highly dissimilar tasks. Although the attributed features make the sector rife with potential to capitalize on robotic automation, the effective integration of robotics into construction has not yet occurred, an outcome-driven by the highly variable nature of construction tasks, minimal industrialization of construction processes, challenges in the scalability and adaptability of technology, and stakeholders’ systematic resistance to change. The question arises: how do we efficiently make this transition with the fewest barriers to entry? To address this question, this project, coined LEAP, studies the acceptability of robot technology. LEAP is based on the idea that the future of work lies in promoting harmonious growth between technology and workers’ capabilities, addressing misalignment between the implementation of innovations and the current allocation of work, thereby fostering the advancement of automation in labor-intensive sectors. LEAP posits that the best path for success is to incrementally empower workers to leverage the human-technology partnership. The project’s results will facilitate the development of upskilling models with technology for the engineering workforce, a scope that falls under NSF Big Idea of FW-HTF. Lessons learned from designing and administering the technology demonstration may apply in many other industrial manufacturing sectors.

The project’s vision is to promote a gradual and smooth transition to a human-technology partnership that sees automation integrated alongside human workers. The project studies the acceptability of robot technology through the embodiment of human-technology interactions, embodiment refers to the coupling of an object and a (human) agent’s body such that control can be exerted to operate on the environment. Using an exploratory (pilot) study, LEAP looks for understanding the underlying cognitive mechanisms of embodiment and their effects on acceptance of robotics by construction workers. LEAP explores the worker’s visual perspective and haptic sense with a focus on inhibitors and stimulators to inform changes in social attitudes toward robots. The research will advance and benefit the FW-HTF by pioneering the exploration of embodiment in workers’ tasks for future robot-worker interactions. LEAP will explore the understanding of robotic capabilities for construction site operations and build new principles for robotic-technology acceptance and compliance in the construction industry. Ultimately, LEAP will increase the understanding of the workers’ individual differences and develop a transformative framework for individual workers’ strategic changes to current operations. Results are expected to contribute to the acceleration and growth of robotic-technology use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The construction industry employs millions of workers in the United States and is a cornerstone of the US economy. Unfortunately, productivity growth has stagnated compared to other economic sectors, often attributed to low productivity rates, labor shortages, an aging workforce, and highly dissimilar tasks. Although the attributed features make the sector rife with potential to capitalize on robotic automation, the effective integration of robotics into construction has not yet occurred—an outcome driven by the highly variable nature of construction tasks, minimal industrialization of construction processes, challenges in the scalability and adaptability of technology, and stakeholders’ systematic resistance to change. The question arises: how do we efficiently make this transition with the fewest barriers to entry? To address this question, this planning research project, called LEAP, studied robot technology's acceptability. LEAP is based on the idea that the future of work lies in promoting harmonious growth between technology and workers’ capabilities, addressing misalignment between the implementation of innovations and the current allocation of work, thereby fostering the advancement of automation in labor-intensive sectors. LEAP posits that the best path to success is to empower workers to leverage the human-technology partnership incrementally. LEAP’s vision is to promote a gradual and smooth transition to a human-technology partnership that integrates automation with human workers.

 The project studied the acceptability of robot technology through the embodiment of human-technology interactions—embodiment refers to the coupling of an object and a (human) agent’s body such that control can be exerted to operate on the environment. Using an exploratory (pilot) study, LEAP looked to understand the underlying cognitive mechanisms of embodiment and their effects on construction workers’ acceptance of robotics. LEAP explored the worker’s visual perspective and haptic sense, focusing on inhibitors and stimulators to inform changes in social attitudes toward robots. To achieve the LEAP’s goal, the PIs developed a scalable, immersive, interactive Virtual Reality (VR) environment platform to implement three main activities for experimentations:

(i)             Characterization of workers’ actions in construction processes with the potential for substitution through automation;

(ii)            Modeling workers’ tasks at different levels of automation to build virtual tasks at different levels of automation;

(iii)          Building worker-robot tasks in a multisensory (haptic and visual) immersive environment, where workers could experience a first-person perspective and agency with haptic features (dexterity movement with haptic feedback).

These activities enabled visual and haptic simulations, including a study with a focus group (construction workers), with the following conclusions:

  • Workers are open to increasingly incorporating robotic technology that helps them perform repetitive tasks, particularly those that are physically taxing. This conclusion is essential across the construction workforce, where inefficiency and injuries are prevalent.
  • Most typical robot designs (manipulators and platforms) lack the flexibility and adaptability to be pre-programmed to perform construction tasks. Implementations in construction require significant effort to perform single (standard) tasks— a challenge to the construction industry as processes demand non-standard operations. A promising attempt is using humanoids, which are highly flexible for learning and adaptation for operating in complex spaces.
  • Construction operations using humanoids in unstructured environments still present challenges. Most were related to unpredictable conditions for mobility and balance, dexterous movements, mechanical robustness to adverse environmental conditions, payload capacity, and uncertainties in object recognition— techniques such as reinforcement learning promise to address some of these issues.
  • It is essential to implement strong simulation ecosystems that enable embodiment (e.g., worker-robot awareness and connection with the worker's physical sensations), including sensory modality feedback from immersive real-world simulations.

The outcomes of the LEAP project will help researchers explore how workers interact with robots in their tasks. This initiative has enhanced our understanding of the capabilities of robots on construction sites and established new principles for how robotic technology can be accepted and used in the construction industry. The results are anticipated to boost the adoption and growth of robotic technology. Additionally, this planning project will aid in developing training models that incorporate technology for the engineering workforce, aligning with the NSF Big Idea of Future Workforce at the Human Technology Frontier (FW-HTF). The lessons learned from designing and implementing the technology demonstration may also apply to various other industrial manufacturing sectors.
